edge: John Wick: Chapter 4 is a 2023 American neo-noir action thriller film directed and co-produced by Chad Stahelski and written by Shay Hatten and Michael Finch. The sequel to John Wick: Chapter 3 – Parabellum (2019) and the fourth installment in the John Wick franchise, the film stars Keanu Reeves as the title character,

In New York City, John Wick prepares to exact vengeance against the High Table while hiding underground with the Bowery King.

In response, High Table member Marquis Vincent Bisset de Gramont summons New York Continental Hotel manager Winston and his concierge Charon, where he explains that the High Table has given him unlimited resources to kill John and chastises Winston for previously failing to do so. As punishment, the Marquis then enlists Caine – a blind, retired High Table assassin – to kill his old friend John, threatening to murder Caine’s daughter.
The Marquis strips Winston of his managerial duties, declares him 'excommunicado', destroys the New York Continental and executes Charon.

node_2: stahelski described an early cut of john wick: chapter 4 as "screwed" because the expanded worldbuilding of its title character and the introduction of new characters took 225 minutes of screen time.
edge: The production process for John Wick: Chapter 4 involved a lengthy initial cut, which Stahelski criticized due to its extended runtime caused by extensive worldbuilding and new character introductions.

node_2: nathan orloff edited the film substantially to reduce the runtime to 169 minutes.
edge: To mitigate issues caused by its initial cut, Nathan Orloff undertook extensive editing of John Wick: Chapter 4 to shorten its runtime.

In the United States, John Wick: Chapter 4 was projected to gross $65 million to 70 million from 3,855 theaters in its opening weekend.
In Canada, John Wick: Chapter 4 was projected to gross $65 million to 70 million from 3,855 theaters in its opening weekend.
In its debut at the box office, John Wick: Chapter 4 made $73.8 million, marking the best opening weekend of the franchise.
In its debut at the box office, John Wick: Chapter 4 surpassed the record for the best opening weekend for an R-rated film released since March 2020.

On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 94% of 374 critics' reviews for John Wick: Chapter 4 are positive, making it a film that has received overwhelmingly favorable reactions from critics.
The average rating for John Wick: Chapter 4 on the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes is 8.1 out of 10, indicating that it has been well-received by critics.

edge: In the consensus statement on the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, John Wick: Chapter 4 is described as 'piling on more of everything' and suggesting that when it comes to Keanu Reeves' lethally balletic style of dispatching his enemies, there can never be too much.

node_2: brilliant, stripped-down, 100-minute classic of a drive-in action film
edge: Somewhere inside the utterly unnecessary, bloated running time for John Wick IV, there's a brilliant, stripped-down, 100-minute classic of a drive-in action film.
the admittedly breathtaking action sequences don't grind on for so long that they become borderline tedious.
According to Nerdist's Michael Walsh, John Wick: Chapter 4 is on the very short list of greatest action movies ever made.
Liz Miller of Consequence gave John Wick: Chapter 4 a C+ and stated that watching the film sometimes felt like watching an above-average assembly cut.
At an unwieldy two hours and 49 minutes, your eye will immediately be drawn to what cuts through the noise – and there are plenty of these moments.

Charles Bramesco of The Guardian wrote that those who appreciated the original for its brutal, sinewy agility have another thing coming: a lumbering, stultifying gargantuan of a film willing to kill everything except its darlings.

Initially, a fifth film was intended to be shot back-to-back with Chapter 4. However, due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on production for Chapter 4, these plans were no longer moving forward.

The ending of Chapter 4 was being reworked to conclude the series with Wick's death, as plans for a sequel were abandoned due to the skepticism of Stahelski over his ability to deliver two uniquely special experiences.

Although Stahelski and Reeves insisted that Wick was dead, Lionsgate initially demurred at the duo's plan to retire Reeves' character. However, due to Chapter 4's 'astonishing' box office, Lionsgate president Joe Drake later hinted at the possibility of a fifth film.
Stahelski stated that he was open to a sequel.
